description.div: Belgium, situated at the crossroads of Western Europe, presents a fascinating linguistic mosaic. The northern region (Flanders) is predominantly Dutch-speaking, while the southern region (Wallonia) is primarily French-speaking, with a small German-speaking community nestled along the eastern border with Germany. Brussels, the capital, presents an intriguing linguistic anomaly: despite being geographically surrounded by Dutch-speaking territories, it functions largely as a French-speaking enclave—a linguistic island shaped by the historical prestige French maintained throughout the region for centuries.

Urban centers like Brussels have become important sites for linguistic landscape research, where scholars analyze public written language on signs, advertisements, and official notices to understand language distribution and power dynamics. However, these conventional linguistic landscape methodologies primarily capture formal, public language usage while often overlooking private linguistic practices.

The Thakbong project expands traditional linguistic landscape research by examining language choices in burial sites and prayer spaces—intimate domains where cultural identity, personal history, and communal belonging intersect. By documenting linguistic practices in these sacred spaces, the project reveals dimensions of language use that remain invisible in standard public signage studies, offering deeper insights into authentic community language practices and heritage preservation.
Belgium has been one of the founding members of the European Community.
East Flanders is a province of Belgium, located to the east of the province West Flanders and the south of the Dutch provinde Zeeland. The capital and biggest city of East Flanders is Ghent.

Ghent is the capital and the biggest city of the province East Flanders. Located at the confluence of the Rivers Scheldt and Leie. It is a port town and a university town and the third largest city of Belgium.

Westerbegraafplaats means literally the Western Burial Ground, located, as the name indicates, to the west of the city center. The Westerbegraafplaats is a large and diversified cemetery, having, among others, sections dedicated to war graves of different nations.

text.transcription: SACRARIO MILITARE/IN MEMORIAM/TOMBE DI BAMBATTENTI ITALIANI/1914-1918/UNUCI-BELGIO

description.div: The image shows a few monuments in the older part of the Westerbegraafplaats.

text.transcription: OPENINGSUREN/WESTERBEGRAAFPLAATS/Van april tot en meet 30 september/van 7 tot 20 uur/Van oktober tot en met 31 maart/van 8 tot 17.30 uur/Toegang verboden bij hevig rukwinden (vanaf code oranje)

normalization.div: Van april tot en meet 30 september van 7 tot 20 uur.
Van oktober tot en met 31 maart van 8 tot 17.30 uur.
Toegang verboden bij hevig rukwinden (vanaf code oranje).

description.div: A site marker, indicating the opening and closing time of the cemetery.
Remarkable is the reference to wind, probably as a disclaimer in case a visitor to the cemetery is hit by a falling branch or a falling monument.

text.transcription: ICI REPOSENT DES COMBANTTANTS FRANÇAIS/HIER RUSTEN FRANSE STRIJDERS/HIER RUHEN FRANZÖSISCHE SOLDATEN/HERE REST FRENCH SOLIDIERS

names.name: Site marker of the "French Military Cemetery"
marqueur de site du "Cimétiere Militaire Français"

description.div: Limburg, or Belgian Limburg, is one of the five Dutch-speaking provinces of the region of Flanders. Part of Limburg is the Dutch-speaking enclave Voeren in the French-speaking province Liège.

Not much fieldwork has been done in Limburg so far. Of particular interest for fieldwork would be the municipality of Voeren in the French-speaking province Liège with respect to the visibility of Dutch and French respectively, compared to other municipalities of Belgian Limburg and Liège.
Kinrooi is a municipality in the arrondissement Maaseik, Belgium.
Kinrooi is a settlement in the arrondissement Maaseik, Belgium. It has the administrative status of a municipality.
Ophoven is a community in the north of Kinrooi.

ent.description: A wooden cross, uninscribed. The grave is covered by an uninscribed slate. The cross and the slate seem to have been applied recently to a grave that is older. The size of the grave might hint to the grave of a child. It might be worth to revisit the tomb to find out whether the grave markers are permanently uninscribed, of whether the photo of 2013 represents an itermediate state in the creation of a grave.

description.div: A black and white photo of Antoinetteke Coolean in her first year of life. The photo is printed on an oval ceramic support nicely surround by two golden circles. The two screws that hold the photo on the tombstone are rusting but have been obviously replaced a number of times.
A black-and-white photo of a newborn baby.
